s2.title: Overview
s2.p: The roles of each component (Cocoon, Slide, Wyona) are described below the overview.
NOTE: Slide is not used so far, but is intended to be used.

s2.title: What is the role of Cocoon
s2.p: At the moment Cocoon is used as XML Publishing Framework. Cocoon's "pipeline processor" controls the interaction between XML and XSLT and provides a mechanismn to map requests to pipelines. More information can be found at the Cocoon website.

s2.title: What is the role of Slide
s2.p: Slide provides a Content Management Framework based on a Java API, which is similar to JSR 170. It can be used as a Data Abstraction Layer accessing various types of content repositories. Slide has implemented a WebDAV servlet which iteracts with Slide's CM API. More information can be found at the Slide website.

s2.title: What is the role of Wyona
s2.p:
Wyona had it's own "Pipeline and XInclude Processor" when it was started in autumn 1999. In the meantime Cocoon and Slide have emerged and developed into powerful frameworks. Wyona started to integrate Cocoon's pipeline processor at the end of 2001. In order to base Wyona on a generic Content Management API we are currently discussing how to integrate Slide. Beside the features of Cocoon and Slide, there are still many features needed to provide a usable Content Management System. Wyona is providing the following additional features:
Authoring/Staging user interfaces for authors and editors
Administrator interface (User/Group/Policies management, Monitoring, etc.)
Resource/Content Creator implementations
Editor interfaces for not WebDAV enabled editors such Xopus and Bitflux
Rudimentary HTML Form Editor as fallback
Scheduler
Workflow Manager
Framework for Publications
Dependency Manager
Notifier/Dispatcher/Subscriber pattern (Event Monitoring, JMS!)
Publisher/Replicator
Access Controlling (Wyona and Cocoon and Slide have each it's own Access Controller!)
etc.
